Jae- Sik Min; Hyung- Sang Park; Sang- Won Kang

Metal-organic atomic-layer deposition of titanium-silicon-nitride films
Jae- Sik Min, Hyung- Sang Park, and Sang- Won Kang<sup>a)</sup>  Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Taejon, Korea
Titanium- silicon- nitride films were grown by metal- organic atomic- layer deposition at

. When silane was supplied separately in the sequence of a tetrakis(dimethylamido) titanium pulse, silane pulse, and ammonia pulse, the Si content in the deposited films and the deposition thickness per cycle remained almost constant at 18 at.

As the minimum feature size of semiconductor devices shrinks, the
diffusion barrier must be effective even when it is as thin as
because thick diffusion barriers leave little space for
, and thus, nullify the advantage of
metallization.<sup>1,2</sup> In this respect, more effective
diffusion barrier materials with a thinner thickness are required. Amorphous refractory ternary metals such as

do not have fast diffusion paths such as a grain boundary present in polycrystalline materials and are promising candidates for these applications.<sup>3,4</sup> These diffusion barriers need to be deposited with good step coverage, especially on the sidewall, as the aspect ratio of contact/via/trench increases.

Metal- organic atomic- layer deposition (MOALD) achieves near- perfect step coverage and can control precisely the thickness and composition of grown films.<sup>5</sup> We have already demonstrated that TiN film could be grown with excellent conformality by MOALD using tetrakis(ethylmethylamido)titanium and

.<sup>6</sup> However, MOALD of a ternary system may not be as easy to demonstrate as much as it is for a binary system and may not be understood straightforwardly in terms of chemical composition and growth kinetics. Therefore, in the present study, we have developed a MOALD technique for ternary
films using a sequential supply of
film with high- frequency small- signal capacitance- voltage

. TDMAT was delivered from the bubbler
to the reactor using Ar (70 sccm) as a carrier gas. Also, the flow rates of
Ar) diluted in Ar were fixed at
. The film thicknesses were measured by the
surface profilometer. The composition of the grown film was analyzed using
elastic recoil detection time of flight (ERD- TOF),
Rutherford backscattering spectroscopy (RBS), and Auger electron spectroscopy (AES).
